intro: Commiphora hirtella, commonly known as the African myrrh, is a small evergreen shrub native to eastern Africa. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes frankincense and myrrh-producing plants. The plant is characterized by its dense, leathery leaves and small, inconspicuous yellow flowers. It produces a fragrant resin, which has been traditionally used in incense and medicinal applications. The botanical features of Commiphora hirtella make it an important species in both ecological and cultural contexts.
